description:
[Dim sum](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim_sum) are shared small dishes or steamer baskets of dumplings and other typically bite-sized foods.

**History**

Dim sum dishes originated from all over China and some even have Western influences, but dim sum as a Hong Kong and [Cantonese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine) (The English spelling is close to the Cantonese pronunciation *dím sām*) originated in the *yum cha* (drink tea) tradition of travelers stopping at teahouses for tea and snacks.

Dim sum is known for being served in on carts in large restaurants, but these days it can be found in a variety of settings ranging from banquet-sized restaurants to cozier Hong Kong-style cafes (cha chaan teng) and ordered off a menu.

**Books**

The Dim Sum Field Guide by Carolyn Phillips and (for kids) Dim Sum for Everyone! by Grace Lin.

**Characters**

The first character [點](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/點) means *a bit* or *a touch*, and the second character [心](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/心) means *heart*, so it can be translated *a touch of heart* or *touching the heart* (Grace Young in Breath of a Wok translates it as *a dot on the heart*.) Anyway, the origin of the term is debated.

Rhymes with “Be careful!” (小心 síu sām), “happy” (開心 hōi sām) and the vegetable “choy sum” (菜心 choi sām).
